description: From Latin supplementum (“that which is added to supply a shortage”), from supplere (“to provide something”).

entries.meaning: Something added, especially to make up for a deficiency.
An extension to a document or publication that adds information, corrects errors or brings up to date.
An additional section of a newspaper devoted to a specific subject.
(geometry) An angle that, when added to a given angle, makes 180°; a supplementary angle.
(nutrition, bodybuilding) A vitamin, herbal extract or chemical compound ingested to meet dietary deficiencies or enhance muscular development.
A surcharge, additional cost, especially for food in a restaurant.
examples: There is a £2 supplement if you choose the steak.

verbs.description: supplement (third-person singular simple present supplements, present participle supplementing, simple past and past participle supplemented)

entries.meaning: To provide or make a supplement to something.
examples: I supplement my income by working as a model.
